I showed him my sketchbook and he signed it. Then, he drew a few lines on the page, which looked like a cloud or the sea. I was thrilled and started talking to him. After a while, I went back to my boat, but my friend told me to go back and draw his portrait. I was nervous, but I returned and asked Picasso if I could draw him. He agreed, and he even acted out different faces for me to draw. He was very playful and made it hard for me to draw him. But I didn't give up, and eventually he relaxed and let me draw him properly. I was amazed by how young and energetic he looked, despite being 84 years old. He was very kind and generous, and I was grateful for the experience. Here is the simplified text for a learner of level B1 on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR):

**Talking shop: How shops make us spend money**

Do you ever go to a store and buy more things than you planned to? Shops use special tricks to make us spend our money. Here are some of them:

**A. Fresh and clean**

Supermarkets put fresh fruit and vegetables at the entrance to make us feel good about buying them. They also make sure the store smells nice, like freshly baked bread. This makes us want to buy more.

**B. Where things are placed**

Shops put the things they want us to buy in easy-to-reach places. They also put the most expensive things in the middle of the store, so we have to walk past them.

**C. Tempting us to buy more**

Shops put cheap things, like bread and sugar, in different parts of the store. This makes us have to walk past other things we might want to buy.

**D. Making things look special**

Some shops make their products look special by displaying them in a certain way. This makes us think they are more valuable than they really are.

**E. The total bill**

Shops want us to buy a lot of things, so they put cheap and expensive things together. This way, we might buy more things than we planned.

**F. The price**

Shops care about the price of their products. They want us to think that something is a good deal if it's a little cheaper than something else.

**G. Lighting**

Shops use special lighting to make things look good. This helps us see what we are buying.

**H. Walking through the store**

Shops make it easy for us to walk through the store by using different carpets. This makes us want to explore and find more things to buy.

**I. In-store promotions**

Shops use big pictures and videos to make us want to buy things. They also use special screens to show us ads as we shop.

Note: I have simplified the vocabulary, sentence structure, and grammar to make it more accessible to a level B1 learner. I have also removed some technical terms and jargon to make the text more understandable.<|eot_id|>

|end_header_id|>

Apples have been around for thousands of years. People have been eating them since ancient times. In the past, people would plant apple seeds and take care of them. They would also dry and store apples for the winter.

In the Middle Ages, people in Europe learned how to grow apples from the Romans. They grew many different kinds of apples, including the famous 'Decio' apple. But most of these apples didn't grow well in Britain, so people started growing new kinds of apples.

In the 17th century, apples became very popular in Britain. People started growing them in their own gardens and orchards. Some apples were taken to other countries, like North America, Australia, and South Africa, by people who settled there.

In the 19th century, a Quaker farmer in Iowa discovered a new kind of apple. He named it 'Delicious' and it became very popular. Another famous apple was discovered in Australia by a woman named Maria Anne Smith. She was a midwife and took care of an apple tree that grew from a discarded apple core. The apples from this tree were green and became famous all over the world.

Today, apples are grown all over the world. Most apples are grown for commercial purposes and are chosen for their red skin or because they travel well. But many people are starting to demand more variety in apples. We need to make sure that we protect the diversity of apples and other foods.

When you ring the solar-powered doorbell, it is very quiet inside because the house is very well-insulated. The windows are triple-glazed and filled with a special gas called krypton, which keeps the noise out.

When you enter the house, you have to take off your shoes because Robert likes it that way. The house is very quiet and peaceful. It's a sunny day, but the windows are closed and the conservatory is warming the air before it ventilates the house. Robert explains that they need to create a draft because they want to make sure the air is fresh.

The Vales are very serious about the environment. They wrote a book about green architecture in the 1970s. They designed a house that doesn't produce any carbon dioxide. They also designed a system to collect rainwater and use it for washing and drinking. They don't have a dishwasher because they don't like using strong detergents.

The Vales don't pay any water bills, and their electricity bill is very low. They will soon install solar panels to generate electricity and heat water. They even plan to charge an electric car one day.

It's warm in the house, even in winter. Robert says it's because there are no draughts and no heat loss. He claims that people who live in old houses should just wear more clothes to stay warm, like people did in the past. The house is simple and low-tech, and almost nothing can go wrong. It's an affordable house, and it's a good example of how we can live more sustainably.'<|eot_id|>

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of English at level B1:

Margaret Wilkins has a special skill. She can find water using a forked hazel stick. Many farmers come to her when their wells dry up. She and her husband run a well-drilling business. They use machines to drill wells, but Margaret uses her special skill to find the water. She can find water more than 90% of the time.

Margaret's skill is called dowsing. There are different theories about how it works. Some people think it's because everything on Earth vibrates, and dowsers can sense these vibrations. Others think it's because dowsers have a special connection to the Earth.

Margaret's customers are mostly farmers who need water for their farms. She tries to find water between 50 and 70 meters deep. She looks for areas where the water is safe and can be brought up without harming the environment.

To find water, Margaret uses a pendulum and a map. She holds the pendulum still and moves it over the map. When it swings, it means there is water below. Then she walks over the fields with her hazel stick. When she is above the water, she feels a strange sensation. She uses the stick to find the exact spot to drill.

Margaret's husband also dowses, and they usually agree on the spot to drill. If they don't agree, they keep looking until they do. Margaret says her skill is an "intuitive perception of the environment". It's hard to explain, but it helps her find water accurately.

Here is the simplified text for a learner of level B1 on the CEFR:

**We Swapped Lives for a Day**

Have you ever wanted to try something new and exciting? Four people did just that - they swapped lives with someone else for a day. Let's hear about their experiences.

**Amanda's Story**

Amanda is a young mother of two daughters. She swapped lives with her friend Cindy, who works as a waitress at a busy restaurant in London. Amanda was surprised by how loud and busy the restaurant was. She had to learn how to carry trays of drinks quickly and efficiently. It was hard work, but everyone was friendly and helpful. Amanda realized that being a waitress is not just about serving food and drinks, but also about being friendly and patient.

**Cindy's Story**

Cindy is a mother of two young daughters. She swapped lives with Amanda, a farmer. Cindy was surprised by how much work it is to take care of two small children all day. She had to get them dressed, fed, and ready for school. Then she had to do household chores like cleaning and laundry. Cindy was exhausted by the end of the day, but she enjoyed spending time with her daughters.

**Rosemary's Story**

Rosemary is a farmer who owns a dairy farm. She swapped lives with Hilary, a teacher at a primary school. Rosemary was surprised by how much work teachers do. She had to get up early, teach classes, and help with sports and activities. She was tired by the end of the day, but she enjoyed meeting the children and seeing how they learn.

**Hilary's Story**

Hilary is a teacher at a primary school. She swapped lives with Rosemary, a farmer. Hilary was surprised by how much work it is to run a farm. She had to milk cows, feed animals, and do chores all day. She missed the children and the structure of her teaching job. She realized that farming is a lot of hard work and not as romantic as it seems.

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of level B1 on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR):

**Leadership is Important**

To be a good leader, you need to inspire others and show them the way forward. It's not about being tall or smart. A good leader is someone who makes things happen with the help of others. They must be enthusiastic and able to speak clearly and confidently.

According to some experts, most people have the potential to be leaders, but they need to recognize and develop their skills. We are all born with leadership qualities, but we need the right circumstances to bring them out.

**What Makes a Good Leader?**

A good leader is someone who motivates and supports their team. They set goals and achieve them. A bad leader makes people feel unimportant and keeps them in the dark. They blame others when things go wrong.

**Leaders and Managers**

Leaders and managers are different. Managers follow rules, while leaders create their own way. A good leader can transform a company or team, while a good manager can keep things running smoothly but not make any real changes.

**How to Become a Better Leader**

If you want to be a better leader, you need to:

* Find your passions and convictions and act on them
* Recognize your leadership abilities and use them
* Be willing to take risks and learn from mistakes
* Learn to delegate, motivate, and communicate effectively
* Be visible and accessible to your team, but also know when to step back and let others take the lead

Note: I've kept the original text's structure and content, but simplified the vocabulary and sentence structures to make it more accessible to a B1-level learner.<|eot_id|>

Newspaper companies are trying to find new ways to make money. They are building walls around their websites to charge people to read their articles. But they are also finding that offering a package deal - print and online access - is the best way to attract readers. Print newspapers still make more money from advertising than online newspapers. However, keeping both a print and online newspaper is expensive and complicated. Newspaper brands still have a strong reputation in print, but it's harder to get noticed online."

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of English at the B1 level (CEFR):

**Photographing People**

People are the most interesting subjects to photograph. Adding a person to a picture makes it more interesting than taking a picture without one. However, photographing people can be challenging. The photographer needs to consider not only technical and artistic aspects but also the person's actions, gestures, and expressions.

**Tips for Taking Good Pictures of People**

A. **Group Shots**

* Don't take pictures of groups in straight lines. Ask people to stand at different angles and distances.
* If possible, have some people sit or kneel at the front so everyone's faces are visible.

B. **Posing**

* People often act unnatural in front of the camera. Help them relax by finding a comfortable position. Suggest they fold their arms or put their hands in their pockets.

C. **The Right Approach**

* Don't pretend you're not taking a picture when you are. This can cause tension and even hostility. Most people will agree to be photographed and are flattered by it. However, they may become self-conscious, so you may need to direct them.

D. **Eye Contact**

* A picture becomes more interesting if the person looks directly at the camera. Ask the subject to look into the lens, not just smile. This will create a natural expression.

E. **Candid Concentration**

* Instead of direct eye contact, ask the subject to focus on something within the picture area. This can be easier and more natural. The viewer can follow their attention to another part of the picture.

F. **Expressions and Gestures**

* Facial expressions and gestures tell us more about the person than anything else. Look for familiar expressions like smiles, winks, anger, tears, and thumbs-up.

G. **Situational Interest**

* Shots that isolate a figure or face can be powerful. The background or environment can add extra interest and information about the subject. Try to exclude irrelevant details or blur them by focusing selectively.

H. **Interaction**

* Pictures of people interacting with each other, like talking, arguing, or working together, can be interesting. Look for contact between subjects, like eye contact or physical touch.

I. **People and Places**

* When taking pictures of people in a new place, use a standard or wide-angle lens to show the background. Ask the subjects to come close to the camera and compose the picture so the group forms a foreground interest without obscuring the background.

J. **To Pose or Not to Pose?**

* Decide why you want to take the picture. If it's to remember someone, ask them to pose against a well-chosen background. For family pictures, candid shots are often more lively and memorable.

I have maintained the original text's factual content and structure while simplifying the language to make it more accessible to learners at the B1 level. I have also broken up long sentences into shorter ones and used simpler vocabulary to improve readability.<|eot_id|>

Here is the simplified text for a B1 level learner:

**Emotional Intelligence: The Key to Success**

The way we work is changing. We are no longer judged just by how smart we are or how well we know our job. Now, we are also judged on how well we get along with others and how well we handle our emotions.

In the past, it was important to do well in school and have good grades. But now, it's more important to have good social skills and personal qualities, like being able to work well with others, being flexible, and being able to convince others of your ideas.

This is because many jobs are changing and becoming more team-based. People who can work well with others and handle their emotions are more likely to be successful. These skills are important for any job, no matter what field you work in.

Emotional intelligence is the ability to understand and control your own emotions and the emotions of others. It's not just about being nice to people, but also about being able to have tough conversations and make difficult decisions.

Many companies are now recognizing the importance of emotional intelligence and are teaching their employees these skills. This is especially important in jobs that require a lot of teamwork and communication.

The good news is that emotional intelligence can be developed over time. As we grow older and gain more experience, we can become better at handling our emotions and working with others. This is an important skill to have, especially in today's job market where job security is not always guaranteed.

Emotional intelligence is not a magic formula for success, but it is an important part of being successful in any job.<|eot_id|>

Here is the simplified text for a learner of level B1 on the CEFR:

Ancient Chinese medicine in the West?

Acupuncture is an old treatment that comes from traditional Chinese medicine. It's used to help people feel better from many different health problems. Doctors in the West are interested in how it can help with pain.

What is acupuncture?

Traditional Chinese medicine thinks that our bodies have a special energy called Qi. This energy flows through our bodies along special lines called meridians. When the flow of Qi is blocked or weak, we can feel sick or weak. An acupuncturist tries to find where the Qi is blocked and helps to get it flowing again.

How does it work?

An acupuncturist uses special needles to help the Qi flow. They might also use heat or pressure to help the Qi move. People often feel a strange but not painful sensation when the needle is inserted.

What kind of pain can it help with?

Acupuncture can help with many kinds of chronic pain, such as back pain, arthritis, and headaches. It can also help with pain after surgery.

How does it work scientifically?

Some doctors think that acupuncture can help by blocking pain signals to the brain or releasing natural pain-relieving substances in the body.

Modern use of acupuncture

Acupuncture has been used in China for over 2,000 years. Recently, it's been used instead of anesthesia during surgery. This has helped some doctors outside of China to understand that acupuncture can be a useful treatment.

Is it always effective?

Not everyone finds acupuncture helpful, but many people do. Acupuncturists say that it usually takes a few visits to start feeling better.

How is it different from Western medicine?

Acupuncturists look at the whole person, not just the symptoms. They try to find the underlying causes of the pain and use a holistic approach to treat it.

What kind of acupuncturist should I see?

It's important to find a qualified acupuncturist who can work with your doctor if needed.

Here is the simplified version of the text for a learner of level B1 on the CEFR:

The Pen is Mightier than the Doctor

Some people think that handwriting can tell us a lot about a person's character. In some countries, employers ask for a sample of your handwriting when you apply for a job. This is because handwriting can give clues about a person's personality, health, and even their potential for certain jobs.

Handwriting analysis, or graphology, is a science that is widely accepted in many countries. Researchers say it can be useful in identifying certain illnesses, like heart disease and cancer, and in understanding a person's emotional state. Many big companies use graphologists to analyze the handwriting of job applicants.

Some experts, like Patricia Marne, a professional graphologist, believe that handwriting can reveal a lot about a person. She says that handwriting can show a person's social class, intelligence, and even their mental ability. She also claims that handwriting can be used to assess whether a person is honest, manipulative, or a reliable employee.

According to Patricia Marne, graphology can also be used to identify potential criminals. She says that criminals often have disturbed handwriting, which can indicate a lack of emotional development. She also claims that graphology can predict whether a person is likely to commit suicide or have heart or lung problems.

Patricia Marne believes that handwriting can also reveal other psychological characteristics. For example, people who write in a certain way may be devious or clever, while those who write mainly in capital letters may be trying to hide their true selves. She says that it takes six years of study and experience to become a good graphologist, and that more research is needed to make graphology a more scientific field.

However, some doctors and psychiatrists are skeptical about the value of graphology. They say that handwriting is influenced by education, artistic ability, and the type of writing taught, and that it has no other significance.

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of level B1 on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR):

'Chewing Gum: A Popular Habit

Chewing gum is a popular habit in the United States, where people chew 12 million sticks every day. But did you know that chewing gum has a long history? Let's find out how it became a big business.

Chewing gum contains very few calories, but it is still considered a food and must meet certain standards. Today, most gum is made from synthetic materials, like pine resin and softeners, which help keep the flavor and texture. But this wasn't always the case.

A long time ago, the ancient Greeks chewed a gum-like substance from the bark of the mastic tree. Women especially liked it to clean their teeth and freshen their breath. American colonists also chewed a resin that formed on spruce trees. This was the first commercial chewing gum in the United States.

In the 1860s, a new type of gum was discovered, made from the sap of the sapodilla tree in Central America. This gum was smoother and more satisfying, and soon a whole industry was born. However, attempts to grow sapodilla commercially have failed.

Today, most gum is made from synthetic materials. The few people who still gather sapodilla have a difficult job, trekking through the rainforest to collect the sap. They face many dangers, including snakes and insects.

Despite the challenges, the remaining sapodilla gatherers are worried about their future. In the past, the United States used to import a lot of sapodilla from Central America, but now they import much less. Gum manufacturers are looking for ways to reduce costs and meet the demand.

In addition to its many uses, gum is also claimed to help reduce tooth decay. When we eat, plaque acid forms, but our saliva helps to neutralize it. Chewing gum can increase saliva production, which helps to protect our teeth. Researchers are still working on new textures and flavors, using ingredients like glycerine and vegetable oils. Some flavors still need natural ingredients, and a lot of mint is grown in the United States to make the most popular gum flavors.'

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a B1 level learner of English:

**Conquering the Seven Summits**

I, Doug Scott, have climbed the highest mountain on each continent. This is my story of adventure and challenge.

**A. Mt. Everest, Asia**

We climbed Mt. Everest, the highest mountain in Asia, in 1970. My climbing partner, Dougal Haston, and I were in a snow cave when he started talking to our guide about sleeping bags. I thought this was strange, but I later realized it was just the effect of high altitude. We were worried about the quality of our survival, not just the fact of surviving. After two days, I relived our time on the summit ridge and realized I had a great climbing partner. I learned to get a better rhythm to reach the summit.

**B. Mt. McKinley, North America**

We climbed Mt. McKinley, the highest mountain in North America, in 1976. The mountain is very difficult and we had to carry our equipment and food up the mountain. We decided to climb 'alpine style', which meant we carried everything with us. We climbed up an avalanche scar and spent the night on a windswept ridge. We were both suffering, but we finally reached the summit.

**C. Kilimanjaro, Africa**

In 1976, my friend Paul Braithwaite and I climbed Kilimanjaro, the highest mountain in Africa. We got lost in the jungle and had to find our way to the summit. We were worried about finding water, but we eventually found a rock pool and continued climbing. We took a new route to the summit, which was surreal.

**D. Aconcagua, South America**

In 1992, I climbed Aconcagua, the highest mountain in South America, with my wife Sharu. We joined a group of climbers going up the Polish Glacier, which was very windy and icy. We decided to miss the glacier and take a safer route to the summit.

**E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica**

In 1992, I climbed Vinson Massif, the highest mountain in Antarctica. We had to guide a team of people to finance our trip. The weather was very cold and windy, but we reached the summit in just 8 hours.

**F. Elbrus, Europe**

In 1994, I climbed Elbrus, the highest mountain in Europe, with a team of climbers. We had to pay a commission to our guide for bringing us into the valley. We climbed to the summit and then returned to the refuge for the night.

**G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia**

In 1994, I climbed Carstensz Pyramid, the highest mountain in Australasia, with a team of climbers. We wanted to establish a new route and spend time with the local Dani people. We climbed to the summit and were given a standing ovation.

I hope this simplified text helps you understand the story of my adventures climbing the Seven Summits.<|eot_id|>

Here is the simplified text for a learner of level B1 on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR):

'Living in the valley We had lived in our valley for 16 months when we first realized that the hills around us could be dangerous. It was a year when the storms came early, before winter even started. Until then, we felt safe and protected in our valley, below the hills. Then snow started falling. It was deep and blocked our path. On the hills nearby, the snow was even deeper and stayed there for a long time. The wind was strong. In our valley, we only felt sudden gusts of wind, but we knew we should be worried. The snow and wind were not a big problem, but the river, the Ryburn, was. It reminded us of what could have happened if the water from the hills hadn't been controlled many years ago. The water was held back by dams. When the snow started melting, we watched the clouds growing bigger and bigger over the hills. The river started to fill up and become wilder every day. We were worried because the reservoir was almost full and could overflow. And then it happened - for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. The water poured down the stream and the river became very wild. We were lucky that the dam held and the water went back down. We had seen this happen before, but now the dam keeps the river from flooding and we can enjoy the big clouds and the power of the river. We feel safe and secure in our valley.'

'I'm Mark Adams, a film critic for The Front Page newspaper. I've been writing about films for ten years now. Before this job, I did some film reviews for a magazine and some radio shows. It was a dream come true to be part of a new newspaper. But it didn't quite work out as planned. We didn't meet as a team, and we did everything by phone. People also preferred to associate a reviewer with one specific area, so I focused on film. Without Tom's idea, I might not be doing what I do now. I like my job because I can write longer pieces about one film, which gives me more freedom. I wouldn't want to review every film that comes out, as it would get boring. Instead, I can make my point and argue my case. I don't think I have to be right about a movie, and I don't think there should be a certain number of "good" or "bad" films each year. A 17-year-old girl named Melanie loves doing triathlons. She swims 1500 meters, cycles 40 kilometers, and then runs 10 kilometers. Some people might think this is crazy, but Melanie says it's fun.

Melanie has been doing triathlons since she was 14. She even won a junior competition once. But sometimes she makes mistakes, like going the wrong way on her bike and having to run extra far. She gets tired and sometimes wants to give up, but she doesn't. She keeps going because she doesn't want to stop and then not want to do it again.

Melanie's coach, Steve, is very impressed with her determination. He says she works very hard and never gives up. Melanie is very good at swimming and running, but she needs to improve her cycling. She is trying to get a new bike to help her train better.

Melanie doesn't have much of a social life because she trains so much. She doesn't like going to parties or talking about clothes and boys with her friends. Instead, she likes to talk about her training and how she can improve.

Melanie wants to do even tougher triathlons than she does now. She wants to find someone her age to train with, but it's hard to find someone who is as dedicated as she is.

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a B1 level learner:

I love collecting things and I'm not alone. Many people enjoy collecting and it's a world of passion and excitement. But remember, if you don't fall in love with an object, don't collect it. People have been collecting things for thousands of years. Even in ancient times, people collected stones and seashells because they liked their shapes and colors. I've been collecting all my life. I started with stones from my parents' garden and then moved on to flowers, pottery, and paintings. When I was a child, my parents would take me to the local museum and I was fascinated by the objects on display. Many people collect things, and the reasons why are interesting. Some people collect because it's the only part of their life where they have complete control. For me, collecting is just something I enjoy doing.

There are many famous collectors, like the Duc de Berry in France, who had a room full of unusual objects. Another famous collector was Catherine the Great of Russia, who had over 4,000 paintings. You don't have to be rich or powerful to start a collection. I've collected all sorts of things, from tulip bulbs to china cups. I've even searched for rare American rag dolls and looked for variations in design. Unfortunately, my collection of 350 rag dolls was destroyed in a fire. It's interesting to see how collections change hands and how the value of objects can increase over time. For example, old toys from the 1950s are now valuable if you still have the original boxes. I wish I had kept mine!

We played cards for a bit, but then we got tired from the journey. There were other people at dinner, including a man and a French couple. In the afternoon, we would drive somewhere. We've done this for years, and we love the different landscapes.

'Chocolate has a long history. It started in South America over 3,000 years ago. Today, it's a big business worth millions of pounds. In the UK, people spend over Â£230 million on chocolate at Easter. This is a lot of money! Only at Christmas do people eat more chocolate.

The cacao tree is a tropical plant that grows in many countries. The fruit of the tree has 20-40 seeds. These seeds are dried and become cacao beans. They can be used to make chocolate.

A long time ago, the Aztecs used cacao beans as money. They also used them to make a drink called xocoatl. This drink was bitter and was used on special occasions.

The Spanish liked the drink better when it was mixed with cinnamon and sugar. But it took another 100 years for the recipe to spread to the rest of Europe. In the 17th century, chocolate houses were set up in big cities. People would gather there to drink chocolate.

In the past, chocolate was made from solid blocks that had to be melted down. But in 1826, a man from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder. This made it easier to make chocolate.

In 1847, a company in Bristol made a solid chocolate bar that you could eat. Later, a Swiss company added milk to the recipe and created milk chocolate.

Today, chocolate is a big business. But some farmers who grow the cacao beans are still struggling. Many of them were forced out of business when the price of cacao beans dropped in the 1980s.'

"Lost luggage is a common problem for travelers. When you arrive at the airport, you might find that your bag is not there. This can be frustrating, especially if you have to wear the same clothes for hours or days until the airline finds your luggage. Some airlines don't tell us how many bags they lose, but it's a fact that sometimes luggage gets lost. Even good airlines can make mistakes. The airline system works like this: they want you to check in early so that your bag has time to get to the plane. They also have rules for connecting flights. These rules are in place to make sure your bag gets to the right plane. But sometimes, things go wrong. Flights are delayed, and bags get lost. This can happen even at big airports. For example, Heathrow Airport in London handles a lot of passengers, and sometimes bags get lost. It's better to take a direct flight if you can. If you have to change planes, try to fly with the same airline. You can also make sure your bag gets to the right plane by giving it a label with your name and address. If your bag still gets lost, you should tell the airline staff at the airport and fill out a special form. You should do this before you leave the airport."

Kingfishers don't actually have blue feathers, but the way their feathers are structured makes them look blue. This is why they can change colour depending on the light. Many photographers love taking pictures of kingfishers because of their beautiful colours and because they can be easy to see if you hide near their favourite spots. Charlie James started hiding near a kingfisher's spot when he was a teenager. It took him four years to get a good picture. He loves kingfishers so much that he missed school and became an "academic failure". But his love for kingfishers led him to work as a photographer and filmmaker. Now, he wants to make a film about kingfishers that just shows their beauty without any words. He loves the simple things about kingfishers, like their colours and the way they move.'

**Conducting an Orchestra**

Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their work.

**A. Anne Manson**

Anne Manson is 30 years old. She asked to attend conductor Claudio Abbado's practice sessions in Vienna. She was surprised when she was asked to help with an opera the next season. She says, "I wasn't nervous. I'm always confident when standing in front of an orchestra." Anne works with a well-known opera company in London and has also worked in other European countries.

**B. Andrew Constantine**

Andrew Constantine, 31, won a big competition in 1991. He says the hardest part of being a conductor is getting people to give him opportunities. He is grateful that he won the competition when he did. It gave him many performance chances and a chance to work with a famous conductor.

**C. Wasfi Kani**

Wasfi Kani, who started Pimlico Opera, loves the long practice time for opera productions. She says, "The music is worth four weeks of attention." Wasfi started conducting in her late 20s. She worked in London's commercial center until her opera company became professional two years ago.

**D. Roger Vignoles**

Roger Vignoles, 48, says conducting came as a surprise to him. However, he enjoyed it and found it fascinating. He started as a musician at an opera house and worked with good conductors. Last year, he directed Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival. He found it easier than he thought and was happy with the result.

**E. Wayne Marshall**

Wayne Marshall, 32, was noticed by conductor Simon Rattle in 1986. He soon found himself conducting a musical in London at short notice. He had to deal with some musicians who were not taking their job seriously. He says, "I was firm with them and got the best result I could." Wayne has never studied conducting formally, but people have been kind to him and he knows what he likes.

Here is the simplified text for a learner of level B1:

**Variations on a Theme: Theme Parks in Britain**

If you want to take your children to a theme park, there are many to choose from in Britain. We asked five families to try out the best ones. Here's what they thought:

**Fun Island**

The Burns family went to Fun Island and were surprised by how much they enjoyed it. The park has lots of rides for young children, so their three-year-old didn't feel left out. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There's even a special ride for the very young kids, which was a big hit. Older kids can try scarier rides like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! The only thing they didn't like was that the park wasn't very exciting to look at.

**Wonderland**

The McMillan family had never been to a theme park before, but they loved Wonderland. Their three-year-old, Oscar, had a great time on the Mountain Train and loved the little replicas of famous buildings. The older kids enjoyed the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a special road. They spent six hours there and were happy to rest their feet. The park is very clean and the staff are friendly.

**Adventure World**

The Jeffree family spent seven hours at Adventure World and still didn't see everything. The kids loved the Big Top Circus and the Terror Line, which was a bit scary. They also enjoyed Running River, where you think you'll get wet but don't. For younger kids, Toy Land is lots of fun. The park is well-designed, so even waiting in line isn't boring. It's also very clean and the staff are great.

**The Great Park**

The Langridge family visited The Great Park and were a bit disappointed that it only closed at 5 pm. The park is great for younger kids because the rides aren't too scary. They loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slow and then gets exciting. They also enjoyed Lightning River, which was over before they knew it!

**Fantasy World**

The Break-all family thought Fantasy World was a lot of fun. They loved Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, and the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 metres high. The older kids went on the main rides several times, but some of the staff were not very friendly.

When Paul was 10 years old, he wanted to play the cello. His parents, John and Hetty, looked for a cello, but it was too expensive. So, John decided to make one himself. He took evening classes at a school for instrument makers and made a few cellos. Paul used one of them until recently.

John now makes violins full-time and sells them to musicians. One of his violins was even bought by a famous American player. Paul and Huw were encouraged to play music from a young age. They started with the piano, but Paul soon moved to the cello.

Paul won a competition and became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra when he was just 20 years old. He played his father's cello until recently, when he got a new one from the Royal Academy of Music. Paul's father is proud of his son's success and has even tried playing his new cello.

Paul will soon perform on television, playing a famous cello concerto. His brother Huw will also perform at the Wigmore Hall that same evening. Their parents will have to work hard to keep track of their sons' musical activities.

**Looking after the countryside**

The National Trust is a group that works to protect the British countryside. I visited the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talked to Gareth Roberts, a warden who takes care of the beautiful areas owned by the Trust.

To be a warden, you need common sense and to be good at dealing with people. Gareth says that's because you have to work with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and building companies.

Gareth was born and grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula. He used to work on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people applied for the job as warden for the Lleyn Peninsula, but Gareth's local knowledge and farming experience helped him get the job, even though he didn't have any special training.

Gareth's farming background is useful because he can understand the problems of local farmers and work with them. He also enjoys the physical part of the job, like building fences and planting trees.

Gareth says that he has learned more about nature conservation since he started working for the Trust. He used to collect flowers and butterfly larvae when he was a child, and now he realizes that farming has changed the countryside. He thinks that farmers and conservationists should work together.

Gareth's job involves making sure that projects are finished quickly and efficiently, and talking to the public. He enjoys seeing projects finished, but sometimes he has to deal with difficult people. He thinks that you need to have common sense to be a good warden.

If you like the outdoors and want to work in a job like Gareth's, you might consider applying to become a warden. But there might not be a job available on the Lleyn Peninsula for a long time.

'My life is all about being the best for the World Championships,' says Kendra. 'I have a strict schedule to get fit.'

These are Kendra's fourth World Championships. This year, 27 countries will take part. 'We'll have home support, which is great,' she says. 'We want to improve the reputation of netball in England. There will be more pressure, but we're ready.' Their first game is against Barbados. 'We usually win, but they're a good team.'

England is ranked fourth in the world. Kendra says the World Championships will be tough. 'You have to play well every day, with no rest between games. But you can still win even if you lose the first game.' In the 15 years she's played at the top level, netball has become faster and harder. 'You don't train to lose,' she says. 'But after the game, we're all friends again.'

Netball is now more scientific about fitness testing. 'We all have to think and train like world-class players,' says Kendra. 'As captain, I lead by example and support my team.' Kendra has planned her netball career carefully. This will be her last big event as a player. She will probably cry during the opening ceremony.'

'Special Music Schools for Gifted Children

Some children show a special talent for music. But it's not always easy to help them develop this gift. Parents may not know how to support their child's musical abilities, and the child may become frustrated if their needs are not met. Most schools are good at helping children who are good at other subjects, but music schools are needed for children who are exceptionally talented in music.

There are five special music schools in Britain that offer a unique environment for children aged 7-18 to develop their musical skills. These schools have professional musicians as teachers and offer a variety of musical activities, such as individual lessons, orchestras, and chamber groups. Students also have time to practice in private rooms with a teacher.

The schools are independent and have small classes with a high teacher-to-student ratio. Most students live at the school, which means they are surrounded by other children who share their passion for music.

However, there are some disadvantages. The schools are expensive, with fees ranging from Â£12,000 to Â£17,000 per year. Some parents may not want their child to live away from home, especially at a young age. The schools also have to make sure that students are not too stressed by the intense musical training.

It's important to consider whether a special music school is the right choice for a child. Some people think that it's better to wait until the child is older before making a decision. Others may prefer a different option, such as a school with a good music department or music lessons on Saturdays. But for families who live near a major city, this option may not be available.'

"Want to get your writing published? If you're not sure where to send your story, Margaret Stubbs is here to help. Many people write to us asking, 'Can you tell me where to send my story?' First, you need to research the market and find out about publishers. You also need to keep improving your writing skills. To get your writing published, you need to know about the writing business. This means reading a lot and finding out what kinds of writing publishers are looking for. You can do this by visiting your local library and bookstores. Reading widely will help you understand what types of writing are popular at the moment. As new publications come out, you need to keep updating your knowledge. 

If you're not sure what kind of writing you want to do, start by finding out which magazines publish the kind of writing you like. For example, if you like writing love stories, find out which magazines publish them and read recent copies. Then, think about what kind of stories these magazines like to publish and who their readers are. These readers will expect certain things from the magazine, and the editor will only publish stories that meet their needs.

Don't send your writing out too early. It's unlikely that your first story will be published. Most successful writers have been writing for a long time before they get published. When you do send your work out, keep writing and improving it while you wait for a response. Write many stories and don't be afraid to make mistakes. Join a writing group or take a creative writing course to help you improve and get ideas from other writers. Think of yourself as a writer and write every day if you can."<|eot_id|>

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of level B1 on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR):

'Dolphins are loved by many people. We enjoy watching them in movies, TV shows, and at the seaside. However, according to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, their situation is very serious. Dolphins are highly intelligent, sensitive, and allow us to dream of a free life in the ocean. This love for dolphins has been encouraged by TV shows like Flipper and Seaquest. But these happy stories hide the reality of life for dolphins in polluted and overfished seas. The number of harbour porpoises in the North Sea has decreased by up to 89,000.

You might expect these popular animals to be protected by law and cared for in special marine reserves. Unfortunately, this is not the case, and the lack of plans to protect them may become one of the biggest environmental disasters of our time.

There are 40 different types of dolphins worldwide. In European waters, the most common are the striped, common, bottlenose, and harbour porpoise dolphins. The striped and common dolphins live far out at sea and are rarely seen. The bottlenose and harbour porpoises used to be common near European coasts, but now they are mostly found in a few areas. The bottlenose dolphins are social and used to be found in the Channel and British rivers, but now they are only found in a few places.

It's difficult to understand why the number of dolphins is decreasing. Overfishing is a major problem, as it reduces the number of fish and threatens local fishing industries. Dolphins also get caught in fishing nets, which can be invisible to them. In recent years, many dead dolphins have been found on French and Cornish beaches, with marks and cuts on their bodies showing that they were caught in nets.

Dolphins can also be poisoned by waste and substances in the sea. For example, pesticides can build up in their bodies and be passed on to their babies. There have been cases of dolphins being poisoned by their mother's milk. The biggest threat to dolphins, however, is human disturbance. Dolphins live in groups and communicate through sound, but noise pollution from ships, oil wells, and other sources can disturb them in ways we don't yet understand.'

But Kendra says the World Championships will be tough. 'You have to give your best every day, there's no rest between games. And you can still win even if you lose the first game. But in the Championships, there's only one chance to win.'

Netball has become a faster and more aggressive sport in the 15 years since Kendra started playing at a high level. 'You don't train hard not to win,' she said. But after the game, everyone becomes friends again.

Netball is also using new methods to test fitness. 'We all need to think and train like world-class players,' said Kendra. As captain, she thinks it's important to have a strong attitude and lead by example. She will support and encourage her teammates.

Kendra has always planned her netball career carefully. She has decided that this will be her last big competition as a player. She will probably coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her last big event. Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she's not teaching, she goes down to the ocean floor in a special vehicle called a submersible. It's like a small car that takes her down to the bottom of the ocean.

Inside the submersible, there's very little space. Rachel has to stay seated and can't stand up or move around. She has to stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can take up to 16 hours. Rachel says it's like being in a small space with the two pilots. They have to work together and can't get out until they reach the surface.

Rachel has made six dives so far. She's been to a place in the Atlantic Ocean where there are many underwater volcanoes. She's studied these volcanoes, called "black smokers", for three years. They're very hot and produce black smoke that comes out of the rock at a rate of one metre per second.

Rachel has had some scary moments during her dives. Once, there was an explosion and she thought she was going to die. But luckily, they were okay. Rachel loves diving to the deepest part of the ocean. She feels a sense of wonder when she looks out of the window and sees the volcanoes.

**Interview Tips**

When we meet someone for the first time, we often form an impression of them quickly. People notice how we dress, our eye contact, body language, and how we speak. Mary Pearce, a teacher, learned this the hard way. She didn't get a job at a school because the Head Teacher thought she didn't present herself well.

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, agrees. He says that if someone doesn't take care of their appearance, they might not care about their job. Many people ignore the importance of dressing professionally. Janet Goodwood, an administrative assistant, was surprised when she wasn't given an interview for a promotion because she didn't fit the image of an office manager.

Our body language and facial expressions also play a big role in making a good impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 55% of our message comes from our facial expressions. We should make sure our words and body language match.

It's also important not to show too much enthusiasm for a job or be too eager to please. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, learned this the hard way. She was offered a job, but the boss offered her a lower salary because he knew she would accept it.

Finally, it's a good idea to prepare for an interview by learning about the company and having a few questions ready. Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests speaking in short sentences and avoiding long, confusing sentences.

**Four Young Sports Stars Talk About Their Lives**

A Darius (runner) I love sports. I used to play many sports, but I was best at football and athletics. When I was 14, I tried out for a professional football team, but I chose to focus on athletics instead. My biggest achievement was competing for my country's youth team and getting a medal. Unfortunately, it didn't get much attention from the media, so I didn't get any sponsorship. I train at home during the winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It's fun, but I have to be disciplined. If friends ask me to go out the night before training, I have to say no. My goal is to go to the next Olympics.

B Gabriel (surfer) The surfing community is small, so we see the same people everywhere we compete. Professional surfers are very serious, and the best waves are often at dawn. If you want to be good, you can't go out late at night. I don't mind giving up late nights, but I love sleeping in, and I usually have to give that up too. It's worth it, because without dedication, I might not have won the National Championships last year. After a win, I like to celebrate with a big night out, and if there's money involved, I'll go somewhere nice. And, of course, the sacrifices are worth it in the long run.

C Dieter (yacht racer) With five friends on a boat, we have a great time. We're traditional and always celebrate a win well. We don't try to get attention from the media, but sometimes they're more interested in where we go out and what we do there than in our racing results. I'm away for eight months a year, so it's great to come back and do normal things with my friends. You can't live, eat, and breathe your sport all the time - it's not healthy. I'm known in the sailing world, but I'm not a celebrity. I get nice letters from people asking for signed pictures, and I always reply.

D Tomas (tennis player) It's great to walk onto the court and feel the crowd supporting you. At the last tournament, it got a bit crazy with people crowding around. I do still get a thrill from being recognized by fans when I'm out shopping, but it has its downsides. My last girlfriend didn't like it when I got too much attention from female fans. As tennis players, we have to travel a lot, and that's why we split up. That was hard, but you have to make sacrifices in any sport. I'm happy to focus on my game now and catch up on the other things in life when I retire.

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes while shopping. Advertisers spend a lot of money trying to get children to want certain products, especially on TV. This can make it hard for parents to explain why they can't buy everything their children want.

Many parents are worried about what their children eat and have ideas about what is healthy. But children may not understand why they can't have certain foods. Parents feel like they are competing with advertisers and it can be hard to say no to their children.

Some parents find it stressful to decide what to buy and what not to buy. One mother says she tries to explain to her son why he can't have certain things, but it's hard to be consistent. Another parent says they sometimes buy things they know are bad for their children just to make them happy.

Supermarkets could make shopping easier for parents by moving sweets to a different part of the store or providing a play area for children. This might make parents want to shop there more often.'

'Ice Skating

Ice skating has a long history. People have been skating for thousands of years. The first skates were made from animal bones. They were used until iron was introduced to Scandinavia, around 200 AD. In Scandinavia, skating was important for the rich people. 

In the early 20th century, skating was popular among the rich. But in 1924, a young girl named Sonja Henie changed the way people skated. She introduced a more athletic style, and this made skating more popular. Today, skating combines art and sport. It is both beautiful and physically demanding.

To start skating, you need to balance and control. You need to be relaxed and move slowly at first. As you get better, you can go faster. The way you stand is important. Keep your knees bent and your weight centred. 

It's important to know how to fall safely. Even good skaters fall sometimes. If you fall, try to relax and roll with the fall. To get up, get on your hands and knees and then stand up.

There are different types of skating, like figure skating, freestyle, and speed skating. But it's best to start with figure skating and then learn freestyle. Most ice rinks have instructors who can teach you.

Skating can help you improve your balance, coordination, and relaxation. It can also make your heart and lungs stronger. Skating is a great way to stay healthy and fit, especially when combined with other sports like swimming or jogging.'

We have a special tank for animals that come to visit. I was late getting home, so I quickly boiled some water. When I arrived, I saw that our cat, Domino, had caught a mouse. The kids were screaming, "Mom, help!"

Domino was running around the room with the mouse in his mouth. He was looking for a way to get out. I tried to help, but I tripped and fell. When I got up, I saw the snake had escaped from its tank. It was slithering around the room. The kids and the cat were all trying to catch it. The snake was hissing and striking. The dog was barking loudly.

I finally managed to catch the cat and rescue the mouse. The snake was very slippery, but I was able to catch it too. I sat on the floor and slowly raised the snake's body. It was very strong and powerful. I decided to let it go in the garden. The kids helped me guide it to a tree. When I finally let go of the snake's head, it slid away and wrapped itself around my shoulders. It was very comfortable there.

We stood there in silence for a moment. Then my oldest son said, "You're nice and warm, Mom, and the shed isn't." I had the kids help me encourage the snake to move away. It slowly went up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last bit of the snake disappeared, my three-year-old son said, "Wow, that was a big snake!"

We've exchanged many letters and have even visited each other. My biggest success was when my family and I visited my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years, and it was amazing that we had never met before. The local newspaper even wrote about it! I'm glad that my children are continuing the tradition. Like my mother, I want them to write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little notes, just like I did to my mother. She and my son have penfriends in Texas, thanks to my penfriend. 'Tourists are damaging ancient rock art in the French Alps. The site, called Mont Bego, has 36,000 drawings on rocks that are 4,000 years old. The drawings show cows, fields, and gods and goddesses. But as more tourists visit, the drawings are being ruined by graffiti. Scientists are worried that if the damage continues, the drawings will not survive for future generations.

Jean Clottes, a scientist, says that people think the drawings will always be there, but they will be gone in 50 years if the damage continues. He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings, wearing them away. Some visitors even take parts of the drawings home as souvenirs.

Experts disagree on the best way to save the drawings. Henry de Lumley, a museum director, thinks the whole mountain should be closed to the public except for guided tours. But Jean Clottes thinks this is too extreme and might cause protests. Another expert, David Lavergne, suggests charging a fee to visit the site to raise money for guards.

Annie Echassoux, a researcher, thinks the site should be roped off and guided tours provided. She believes the government should provide the necessary funds to protect the site, as it is a historic monument.'

**Shopping with Children: A Challenge for Parents**

For many parents, taking their children to the supermarket can be a stressful experience. Children often want everything they see, from the latest cereal to a Disney video or a comic. Parents feel guilty when they say no, but they also don't want to buy things that are not good for their children. It's hard to say no all the time, but saying yes too often can make parents feel guilty.

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes while shopping. The advertising industry spends a lot of money on TV ads, and supermarkets are where they are most successful. Children often don't understand why they can't have everything they want, and the ads make it hard for them to make good choices.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says that parents are concerned about what their children eat, but they may not always know what is healthy. It's important for parents to talk to their children about food, but it's hard to compete with the advertising industry.

Some parents feel stressed when deciding what to buy and what not to buy. One mother says she tries to explain to her son that ads are not always honest, and now they don't argue much about what to buy. Other parents admit that they are inconsistent and sometimes buy things they know are not good for their children.

Supermarkets could help reduce the stress by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing play areas for children. This could make shopping more enjoyable for parents and children alike.

They could only be built straight up and down, not like the cliffs outside. Climbers got bored with the same old holds.

In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny invented a special material that could be shaped like the rocks on cliffs. It could be attached to any wall and taken off when climbers got bored. French companies also tried using steel frames with panels. This made it possible to build walls with overhangs and different angles. Climbers could change the holds and never get bored."

Here is a rewritten version of the text at a B1 level:

Do you want to be an actor? If you tell someone you want to make a career as an actor, they might say it's a risky job. And they're right. There are more people who want to be actors than there are acting jobs available. When you decide to become an actor, some of your friends might think you're crazy, but others might be supportive. Everyone has their own opinion, and it's a personal choice. You're the only one who can make it happen.

It's not easy to become an actor. There's no special exam you need to pass, and there's no guarantee of success. It's a mix of luck and talent. But there are always new opportunities for new faces and new talent. Acting can be exciting, glamorous, and sometimes very rewarding.

People often ask what makes someone a good actor. I think it's a combination of natural ability and imagination. And it takes a lot of courage to believe in yourself and your work. Where does the desire to act come from? It's hard to explain, but for many actors, it's about the connection they make with the audience.

When actors talk about their success, they often shrug and say they don't know. They might know some things about themselves and their skills, but they never take anything for granted. They know that their next job might be their last. Disappointment is a big fear for actors.

Actors often don't talk about their chances of getting a part. They find ways to deal with the stress and rejection. Nobody likes being rejected, and it's a possibility from the start. When you audition for a part, you're saying you're available, willing, and talented. If you don't care, nobody else will.

'Chris Greener is a tall man. He is 228 cm tall, which is the tallest in Britain. When he was 14, he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher asked what he wanted to be. Chris said he wanted to be the flagpole on a ship. This was because he was already very tall at 14.

Did you know that people are getting taller every year? This is because we are eating better food. In the past, people didn't eat as well as we do now. They ate a lot of bread, soup, and porridge. This made them shorter and less healthy.

In the past, people used to eat many different foods, like fruits, vegetables, and animals. But then, people started farming and eating more bread, rice, and corn. This made them taller, but not as healthy.

Now, people are eating better again, and we are getting taller. In some countries, like the US, Holland, and Japan, people are getting taller. But, we can't keep growing forever. There must be a limit to how tall we can get.

Some scientists think that humans were actually shorter and rounder in the past, when it was colder. Now that it's warmer, we are getting thinner and shorter. This means that even if we eat well, we might not get any taller.

So, the question is: how tall can we get? Will we keep growing, or will we stop? Only time will tell.'<|eot_id|>

As you walk around the village, you will see many different buildings, including a castle, a church, and a zoo. You can also play mini golf! Please stay on the paths and don't touch the models. You can take photos from the paths, but not too close. Dogs are welcome on a short lead.

We would love to hear your thoughts about the village. Are there any models that you think need to be improved? We are always planning new models and want to know what you think. We hope you enjoy your visit and will come back again soon.'

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of English at the B1 level (CEFR):

"Every week, British newspapers print pictures that invade people's privacy and break their own rules. Although some famous people agree to be photographed by paparazzi, this is not normal. Usually, people in the public eye suffer when their private moments are published on the front page. However, very few of them ask for help from the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), an organization that is supposed to deal with these kinds of issues. Rarely, if ever, do these pictures serve the public interest. Do pictures of famous people help catch criminals? How did a famous actress's picture on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress has complained about long-lens pictures in the past and since she was in a hotel, where people expect privacy, she had a good reason to complain. But she didn't take any action. The PCC didn't even investigate this case. This is a scandal. 

The PCC should also look into another recent story about a famous pop star's private life. The pop star, like the actress, hasn't made a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take the initiative on this and other cases? At first, this seems like a good idea. It would probably lead to many newspapers being punished. The public would not support them, and editors would have to stop publishing this kind of material. Even photographers would be affected, as they would no longer be able to earn a living by taking pictures of celebrities. 

However, there are some problems with this idea. How would the PCC decide whether to investigate a case? Should it ask the person involved to make a complaint? And if they refuse, should it still investigate? There are also practical difficulties. The PCC would have to monitor all British newspapers, which would be a huge task. Additionally, celebrities and royalty might expect that any story about them would be investigated, and then be upset if it wasn't. 

The main problem is that the role of the PCC is too big. It would be difficult for them to handle all the complaints. There is also the embarrassment factor to consider. Even if someone's privacy has been invaded, they might not want to go through the embarrassment of an investigation. Most people just want to move on with their lives. A few might have other reasons for staying quiet. They might be worried that a worse story about them could come out if they complain. In other words, even the PCC might become the enemy. One comedian was also a victim of the press when his honeymoon pictures were published. He didn't complain then or later when his family was photographed on holiday. His reason was fear that the newspaper would use the pictures again with a new story, saying he was angry, and that, as a comedian, they thought he would find it funny. This fear is understandable. People think they will become targets again if they challenge the tabloids. It's hard to see an easy solution to this serious problem."<|eot_id|>

I decided to go in and found a man named Baba, who was running a small camp. I stayed there for the night, even though I was a bit scared of the insects.

The next morning, I woke up to a beautiful view of the mountains. It started raining in the afternoon, and I got wet. I was worried about my car, but it was still there when I got back. In the town, everyone was very friendly and asked me questions like "Where are you from?" and "How old are you?" I remember my trip more for the kindness of the people than the kites.

**What kind of shopper are you?**

We all go shopping, but people have different ways of doing it. Abby Edwards asked some friends about their shopping habits.

**Some people love shopping**

* Melanie, 22, dancer: I love shopping! I go shopping whenever I have money and I don't feel bad about it. My boyfriend likes shopping too, so we go together.
* Lisa, 22, actress: I like going shopping with my friends. We often find something we like and buy it.

**Some people don't like shopping**

* Brenda, 40, office manager: I don't enjoy shopping. My husband does most of the food shopping, and I don't like buying clothes. When I do buy something, I feel guilty.
* Lizzie, 41, secretary: I hate shopping. I don't like looking for clothes because it's hard to find what I want. The shops are noisy and disorganized.
* Linda, 32, restaurant manager: I don't like shopping because I work in the city centre and it's not fun for me. When I have to go shopping, I just get what I need and don't bother trying things on.

**Some people are careful shoppers**

* Juliet, 28, personnel manager: I only buy what I need. I don't like shopping and would rather do something else.
* Suki, 26, art gallery assistant: I like shopping, but I don't buy much. I usually know what I want and don't spend a lot.

**Some people are happy shoppers**

* Anita, 35, TV producer: I like going shopping, but I know what I want and don't waste time.
* Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker: I love shopping, but only on certain days. I set off with an idea of what I want and look around to find the best deal.

'Gallery News Easter Quiz for Children

During the Easter holidays, children can take part in a fun quiz at the gallery. The quiz sheets are free and can be picked up at the Orange Street entrance. The quiz asks questions about 14 surprising paintings in the gallery. The quiz sheets are available from March 25th to April 9th.

New Picture

The gallery has a new painting by a Dutch artist from the 18th century, Jan van Os. The painting is of flowers and fruit and is very colorful. It is one of the first paintings of its kind in the gallery. The painting was given to the gallery by a kind donor in memory of her sister. You can see the painting in Room 25.

Special Exhibition

The exhibition 'Spanish Painting in the Late 18th Century' is now open in the Sunley Room. The gallery has bought some new paintings by Spanish artists from this period. The exhibition will be open until May 31st.

'Money What is money? The pound, the dollar, or the franc are like a measure of weight or distance. The difference is that you can use money to buy things. A five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or two cinema tickets. But the note itself is just a piece of paper that costs almost nothing to make. A long time ago, people didn't have money like we do now. They didn't have banks or shops. In those days, a farmer named Mr. Green would trade his corn for honey from Mr. Hive. This was a deal between two people, each of whom had something the other wanted. Later, most societies created their own money so people could trade more easily. The different types of money started to work together, which is why we use national money today.'

**Write a Winning Story!**

Do you want to win Â£1,000 and see your story in a magazine? Ten other people will win Â£100. The judges are looking for interesting and original stories. You can write about anything you like, but here's some advice to help you:

**Write about what you know**

Last year, most people who wrote for us wrote about love, family, and friends. But you need to make these ordinary situations interesting and surprising.

**Get your facts right**

Make sure you get the details correct. If you're not sure about something, don't write about it.

**Make the reader want to keep reading**

Start your story with something interesting and end it with a surprise. Think about the characters and make them come alive with your words.

**Your story must be your own work**

Your story must be between 2,000 and 2,500 words, typed and double-spaced. You need to include an application form with your story. Don't send your story by fax or email.

**Important rules**

Your story cannot be printed in any magazine or book in the UK, and it cannot be broadcast on radio or TV anywhere in the world. If you win, you must agree to have your story printed in our magazine.

The closing date is 30 July, and we will contact the winners within a month of this date.<|eot_id|>

The view from the train after Alice Springs is not very interesting, just a lot of flat land with cows. But on the third day, we reached the hills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was over, and although the train didn't quite live up to the promises, it took me to some amazing places in Australia.'

'Every year, many people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. It's a big mountain and the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt tells us about his first time climbing Ben Nevis. It was a winter climb in February. We went up the north side of the mountain to Tower Ridge. It's 600 metres up, which is the longest climb in Britain. We planned to stay in the 'Carries', which are like big bowls cut into the mountain half-way up. We took our tents, sleeping bags, and special spikes for our boots. Without these spikes, it's hard to walk on the snow because it's like walking on ice. We also took safety equipment, like lights and extra clothes. Even though the weather was good, we were still a bit nervous. Ben Nevis is always a challenge. The track was steep and my legs felt heavy. I had to rest more often because I was the weakest in the group. The others would wait for me to catch up, but then we would keep going. I promised myself to train better before a climb next time. After 200 metres, we reached the start of Tower Ridge. It's a narrow path, only 1.5 metres wide, and the mountain drops down hundreds of metres on each side. We had to be careful and focus on every step. It took us seven hours to get to the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, 48 kilometres away. But we weren't lucky that day, as a mist came down. Getting down the mountain can be just as hard as going up. You need to know how to read a map correctly, or you might take a wrong turn and find yourself on a slope that's too steep to climb down in winter. I was glad we took turns reading the map. That first time, I didn't feel happy until I was safe in my tent. But at least I made it to the top.'

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of level B1 on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR):

THE ICEHOTEL

For a long time, the Arctic was a popular place to visit in the summer to see the midnight sun. In the winter, the few people who lived there had the snow and ice all to themselves. In the 1980s, people decided to use the winter weather to their advantage. In 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit was invited to open an exhibition in a special igloo in a small town called Jukkasjarvi. The igloo was called Arctic Hall and many people came to visit.

One night, some foreign visitors had the idea to sleep in the Arctic Hall. They were very happy with their experience and this is how the idea of an ice hotel was born. Today, it's famous all over the world.

Every year, a team of people from all over the world come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel. They use natural materials like snow and ice to build it. The hotel is open to visitors and guests as it is being built, bit by bit. The first part is finished in December and a new part is finished every week after that. The hotel is finished by January 7th.

The hotel is built outside, so the temperature inside is never too cold. It's always between -5Â°C and -8Â°C. You can wear warm clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves, and you can also bring your own. You can even buy warm clothes on the ICEHOTEL website before you come.

The hotel is in a village called Jukkasjarvi, near the Arctic Circle. It's close to an airport and a train station. You can take a bus from the airport or train station to the hotel.

**The Short Story Society**

The Short Story Society is a group that helps writers in the UK. It was started in 1899 and is now one of the most active arts organizations in the country.

**Magazines**

We publish two magazines. One is called the Short Story Review. It has short stories by famous writers and also gives new writers a chance to publish their work. The other magazine is called Short Story News. It has interviews with writers and information about writing events, competitions, and festivals.

**National Short Story Competition**

We run a big competition for short stories. Anyone over 18 can enter. The stories should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. There is no fee for members, but non-members need to pay Â£5. The competition runs from April to October. The best stories will be published in a book, and the winner will get a contract to publish their own book.

**Education**

We have been teaching writing to children and teachers for nearly thirty years. We help them with ideas and build their confidence. We also have a competition for young writers aged 11-18. The winners get book prizes and can attend a five-day writing course with professional writers.

**The Writers' Cafe**

The Writers' Cafe is our social centre. It's a relaxed place with vegetarian food, coffee, and drinks. We have exhibitions, courses, and readings every month. It's in the heart of London and is open from 11 am to 10 pm on weekdays and 11 am to 8 pm on Saturdays. Members get discounts on some products and events.

**Joining the Society**

We have members from all over the world. Anyone over 18 can join. If you're interested, click here to fill out a registration form.

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a B1 level learner:

'TAKE A JOURNEY ALONG THE BEAUTIFUL DOURO RIVER

The MV Lady Ivy May is a special "hotel ship" that sails along the Douro river in Portugal. The ship can take 160 guests in comfortable rooms with private bathrooms. On board, you'll find a sun deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.

Day 1: We fly from London Heathrow to Oporto and meet our guide. We'll take a bus to the ship and spend the night on board.

Day 2: We visit Oporto in the morning and then go back to the ship. We'll sail to Entre-os-Rios, a journey that takes four hours.

Day 3: We continue sailing up the river and stop at Peso da Regua, where we can try some delicious local food and drink.

Day 4: We take a bus to the old town of Lamego and visit the cathedral, churches, and a museum. The museum was once a palace and has a great collection of art and antiques.

Day 5: We sail to Tua, where the river gets very narrow. Depending on the water level, we might take a smaller boat to the Spanish border. If not, we'll take a bus and see some interesting sights along the way.

Day 6: We drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for a beautiful view of the Douro valley. We'll have lunch on the ship and then take a train ride through the countryside to Regua, where the ship will be waiting for us.

Day 7: We visit Vila Real and then return to the ship for lunch. In the afternoon, we'll sail back down the river to Oporto.

Day 8: We arrive in Oporto with plenty of time to explore and do some shopping before we fly back to London Heathrow.'
