What to see During the day, you can walk around the balloons and talk to the pilots. The balloons come in all shapes and sizes, and some are even in the shapes of animals or cartoon characters. In the evening, you can see the balloons light up at the same time, which is called a 'balloon glow'. This is a great time to take photos. You need to be there just after sunset or before 5:30 am. At night, you can take a balloon ride or a cable car to the top of a nearby mountain and see the festival from above. There are also balloon races and fireworks on certain evenings. The Albuquerque Box This is a special wind pattern that helps the balloons fly safely. The nearby mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentle winds at different heights. Skilled pilots can control the direction of their balloons by rising or descending. Practical advice Buy your tickets online in advance to avoid a long wait. Wear layers of thin clothing, as it can be cool at night and hot during the day. Bring a flashlight for night-time events, a camera, and suncream and sunglasses for the day. If you're not a digital photographer, bring high-speed film for evening and night-time pictures.'

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of English at the B1 level (CEFR):

THE IDITAROD TRAIL

In the 1880s, people came to Alaska to find gold. A town called Iditarod grew quickly and became the largest city in Alaska. But in the winter, it was hard to get supplies to the town because the rivers and ocean were frozen. So, in 1910, a special path was built for dogs to pull sleds. They carried mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. This path was called the Iditarod Trail.

It took the dogs about three weeks to travel across Alaska. They stopped at special houses called roadhouses where the drivers could rest and eat. The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes became the main way to travel.

In 1925, a big problem happened. A disease called diphtheria came to Nome, and the medicine to cure it was on the other side of Alaska. The only pilot who could fly in the cold weather was away, so the medicine was sent by dog sled. It was a long journey of over 1,000 kilometers. Twenty teams of dogs and their drivers took six days to complete it.

Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian who came to Alaska to find gold, went the first 400 kilometers with his dog Togo. Togo was very good at finding the way in the snow. The last part of the journey was done by Gunnar Kaasen, who had driven dog teams for 21 years. His lead dog was Saito. At one point, Balto, one of the dogs, refused to go further and saved the team from falling into the icy water. Balto became a hero.

Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the same route as in 1925. It is called the Iditarod and is known as "The Last Great Race on Earth".

Here is the simplified text:

"Winter driving can be dangerous because it's hard to predict what might happen and accidents can happen quickly. Fog can suddenly appear over a hill, and ice can be hidden under the snow, making it easy to lose control of the car. The car in front of you might also slide across the road unexpectedly.

To drive safely on icy roads, remember two important rules. First, drive smoothly and gently. Sudden movements can make your car hard to control, so turn the wheel, press the brakes, or speed up slowly. Imagine you're holding a cup of hot coffee - drive carefully so you don't spill it.

Second, always be prepared for what might happen. Look far ahead when driving on icy roads, as it takes longer to stop. Test how long it takes to stop by gently braking. Remember that you might be going faster than you think. When the road is wet, snowy, or icy, leave more space between you and the car in front of you. Try to stay in control of your car at all times, and you'll be safe."

* Added more concrete examples, such as the cup of hot coffee, to help learners understand the concept

He doesn't follow any artistic traditions and just paints the way he wants to. Despite this, his work still inspires young British painters.

When autumn came, Bill flew to Virginia, 600 miles south of his home. The geese followed him all the way. Bill left the geese in Virginia and went back home. This spring, Bill was waiting for the birds to come back. But they didn't arrive, so Bill went to Virginia to find them. He looked for two weeks but couldn't find them. When he got back home, the geese were waiting for him. They had found their way back home by themselves!'

'THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE

A long time ago, London didn't have any police. A few old men helped keep the streets safe at night, but they weren't paid very much. London was getting bigger and dirtier, and many people were poor. There were a lot of thieves, so people stayed at home. In 1750, a man named Henry Fielding started paying people to stop thieves. They were like police and were called 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London was very big and needed more police. So, in 1829, the first London Police Force was started with 3000 officers. Most of them walked, but a few rode horses. Until 1920, all the police in London were men. Now, London police are well paid, and the few police officers who still ride horses get paid even more.'
